ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic Japanese conversation, know how to write a simple self-introduction, described what I did during the weekend, buy items, and describe the color of clothing.
Great class. Really fun and well taught. Of course the every day meetings and homework wears you down part way through the semester but it does really keep you moving along with the language.
I developed a skill of learning faster and applying what I learned to my skills on a daily basis.
I learned many facets of beginning Japanese. This includes vocabulary, grammar, hiragana, katakana, and almost 70 kanji.
So much. The introductory course of the Japanese language and culture. A fantastic start.

Even though this course is time demanding, this is one of the best I have ever taken. We have learned a lot of tenses, all 3 Japanese alphabets including 70 kanjis, speak easily on any simple topics, and even write essays in Japanese. That amount of work allows you to learn topics in one semester you might learn by doing it yourself for 2 years. Highly recommend it if you like Japanese.
Vocab, grammar patterns, conversational practice of Japanese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course would be better if more reading materials are provided. Maybe some short reading materials can be assigned as homework? The instructor did point us to the Japanese-graded readers in the East Asian Library on the 2nd floor of Sterling. Unfortunately, those books cannot be borrowed.
The daily homework is really helpful. The textbook is great.
A weakness is the quantity of work that was given because sometimes it wouldn't be beneficial in improving language skills and would only add more time to the class preparations/homework.

I like how languages here at Yale meet everyday because it forces you to be engaged with the material to actually succeed. The everyday homework assignments were also helpful to make sure you were putting in the work outside of the class as well.

Strengths: Level of engagement and work.
Weaknesses: Uneven learning speed and starting knowledge. (but this really cannot be fixed as everyone learns at different speeds and has different backgrounds)

No weaknesses! Be only ready for a lot of work, which might be challenging if you prefer something other than Japanese. That should not be a problem as Stever Sensei is the best Japanese teacher. Highly recommend her even if you need to wake up earlier for these classes. She always gives valuable pieces of advice and teaches terrifically!

I really appreciate the emphasis on speaking and conversation, as in past language courses, I have learned that the best way to fully immerse oneself in a language is to engage in conversation using that language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if he or she is interested in learning Japanese I would definitely recommend this course. The course is very well designed.
Yes! It's 1.5 credits, but barely feels like it besides the fact that there is class every day. The homework takes about 20-30 minutes every night, and the tests aren't too hard.
If Japanese is something you're passionate about, I would recommend it. Otherwise, the workload may seem overbearing.

I would recommend this course to another student because Japanese an amazing language to learn. Though it is a good amount of work outside of class, it is awesome to learn about another language and culture.

Yes. Very very hard and lots of work. Significantly more work than any of my other classes, but overall great and highly engaging. I loved it and it also created more stress in my life than any other class.

Even though this course is time demanding, this is one of the best I have ever taken. We have learned a lot of tenses, all 3 Japanese alphabets, including 70 kanjis, speak easily on any simple topics, and even write essays in Japanese. That amount of work allows you to learn topics in one semester you might learn by doing it yourself for two years. Highly recommend it if you like Japanese.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It was a very gentle yet challenging introduction to the Japanese language and made me excited to keep taking Japanese courses in future semesters.
